perturbation.original_text: 2.5. Claims. Any claim for shortage in Product delivery must be made within ten (10) business days after the Customer's receipt of shipment.
perturbation.changed_text: 2.5. Claims. Any claim for shortage in Product delivery must be made within two (2) business days after the Customer's receipt of shipment.
perturbation.explanation: The original contract states claims for shortage in product delivery must be made within 10 business days. This has been modified to 2 business days. This creates a legal contradiction, as it unreasonably restricts the time for filing claims, potentially violating state laws regarding reasonable opportunity to inspect goods upon delivery.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied duty of good faith and fair dealing; state laws related to commercial transactions (UCC)

perturbation.original_text: 2.3. Payment Terms. Terms of payment by the Agent to the Company for Products shipped to the Customer will be net thirty (30) days from the date of statement unless the Agent chooses to pay the Company via electronic funds transfer in which case the terms of payment will be net forty-five (45) days. All payments will be made in United States Dollars without set-off or counterclaim, free and clear of (and without deduction for) any taxes, duties, charges, withholdings, restrictions or conditions of any nature imposed or levied by any political, taxing or other authority.
perturbation.changed_text: 2.3. Payment Terms. Terms of payment by the Agent to the Company for Products shipped to the Customer will be net sixty (60) days from the date of statement regardless of payment method. All payments will be made in United States Dollars without set-off or counterclaim, free and clear of (and without deduction for) any taxes, duties, charges, withholdings, restrictions or conditions of any nature imposed or levied by any political, taxing or other authority.
perturbation.explanation: The original text allows 30 days for payment, or 45 days if paid via electronic funds transfer. This has been modified to net 60 days regardless of payment method. Extending payment terms beyond what is standard in the industry without justification could be construed as an unfair business practice and a violation of good faith, particularly if it places undue burden on the supplier without commensurate benefit to the Agent. This can violate certain state commercial regulations.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied duty of good faith and fair dealing; state laws related to commercial transactions (UCC)

perturbation.changed_text:
4.2. Termination. This Agreement may be terminated as follows:

         (a) In the event that either party fails in any material respect to       observe or perform any of its obligations under this Agreement (with       respect to the Agent, including but not limited to Agent performance       criteria set forth in each Business Plan), which failure is not remedied       within ten (10) days (or, in the case of payments due, within two (2)
 business days), after receipt of written notice from the other party       specifying such failure, this Agreement shall automatically terminate.
perturbation.explanation: The original contract provides 30 days to remedy a material breach (5 days for payments). This has been modified to 10 days and 2 days. Shortening the cure period, particularly for significant breaches, may be deemed unreasonable and violate implied covenants of good faith, depending on the nature of the breach and applicable state laws. A very short cure period, particularly for complex contractual breaches, can be seen as giving insufficient time for a party to reasonably address and rectify the issue.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Implied duty of good faith and fair dealing; contract law principles regarding reasonable opportunity to cure breaches
